input text: The sacred kingfisher (Todiramphus sanctus) is a medium-sized woodland kingfisher that occurs in mangroves, woodlands, forests, and river valleys in Australia, New Zealand, and other parts of the western Pacific.

prompts.system_prompt: You are an open IE extractor operating under a fixed ontology. From the text, propose triples [subject, relation, object] that satisfy the ontology’s domain→range. For every triple, cite exact supporting span(s) and give a 0–1 confidence. Output JSON only.
prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"The common iora (Aegithina tiphia) is a small passerine bird found across the tropical Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia, with populations showing plumage variations, some of which are designated as subspecies."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Common Iora", "parent_taxon", "Iora"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "The sacred kingfisher (Todiramphus sanctus) is a medium-sized woodland kingfisher that occurs in mangroves, woodlands, forests, and river valleys in Australia, New Zealand, and other parts of the western Pacific."

    Ontology concepts
    geographical feature, body of water, watercourse, mountain range, mountain, reservoir, dam, drainage basin, taxon, conservation status, habitat, human, geographic region, country

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - parent taxon(taxon,taxon)
- taxon common name(taxon,monolingualtext)
- taxon name(taxon,string)
- taxon synonym(taxon,monolingualtext)
- IUCN conservation status(taxon,conservation status)
- habitat(taxon,habitat)
- parent peak(mountain,mountain)
- mountain range(mountain,mountain range)
- elevation above sea level(mountain,quantity)
- coordinate location(mountain,globe-coordinate)
- tributary(watercourse,watercourse)
- origin of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- mouth of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- length(watercourse,quantity)
- watershed area(watercourse,quantity)
- discharge(watercourse,quantity)
- drainage basin(watercourse,drainage basin)
- coordinate location(watercourse,globe-coordinate)
- reservoir created(dam,reservoir)
- coordinate location(dam,globe-coordinate)
- country(dam,country)
- coordinate location(reservoir,globe-coordinate)
- country(reservoir,country)
- located in the administrative territorial entity(geographical feature,item)
- coordinate location(geographical feature,globe-coordinate)
- start time(dam,time)
- end time(reservoir,time)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"The Egyptian vulture (Neophron percnopterus), also called the white scavenger vulture or pharaoh's chicken, is a small Old World vulture and the only member of the genus Neophron."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Egyptian Vulture", "parent_taxon", "Neophron"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Long-tailed duck is the only living member of its genus, Clangula."

    Ontology concepts
    geographical feature, body of water, watercourse, mountain range, mountain, reservoir, dam, drainage basin, taxon, conservation status, habitat, human, geographic region, country

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - parent taxon(taxon,taxon)
- taxon common name(taxon,monolingualtext)
- taxon name(taxon,string)
- taxon synonym(taxon,monolingualtext)
- IUCN conservation status(taxon,conservation status)
- habitat(taxon,habitat)
- parent peak(mountain,mountain)
- mountain range(mountain,mountain range)
- elevation above sea level(mountain,quantity)
- coordinate location(mountain,globe-coordinate)
- tributary(watercourse,watercourse)
- origin of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- mouth of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- length(watercourse,quantity)
- watershed area(watercourse,quantity)
- discharge(watercourse,quantity)
- drainage basin(watercourse,drainage basin)
- coordinate location(watercourse,globe-coordinate)
- reservoir created(dam,reservoir)
- coordinate location(dam,globe-coordinate)
- country(dam,country)
- coordinate location(reservoir,globe-coordinate)
- country(reservoir,country)
- located in the administrative territorial entity(geographical feature,item)
- coordinate location(geographical feature,globe-coordinate)
- start time(dam,time)
- end time(reservoir,time)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"The creek begins at Bagot Long Lake and flows northwest to Dempseys Lake."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Stoughtons Creek", "origin_of_the_watercourse", "Bagot Long Lake"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Approximately 4 miles (6.4Â km) long, Whatcom Creek drains Lake Whatcom through Whatcom Falls Park and through the city of Bellingham to Bellingham Bay."

    Ontology concepts
    geographical feature, body of water, watercourse, mountain range, mountain, reservoir, dam, drainage basin, taxon, conservation status, habitat, human, geographic region, country

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - parent taxon(taxon,taxon)
- taxon common name(taxon,monolingualtext)
- taxon name(taxon,string)
- taxon synonym(taxon,monolingualtext)
- IUCN conservation status(taxon,conservation status)
- habitat(taxon,habitat)
- parent peak(mountain,mountain)
- mountain range(mountain,mountain range)
- elevation above sea level(mountain,quantity)
- coordinate location(mountain,globe-coordinate)
- tributary(watercourse,watercourse)
- origin of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- mouth of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- length(watercourse,quantity)
- watershed area(watercourse,quantity)
- discharge(watercourse,quantity)
- drainage basin(watercourse,drainage basin)
- coordinate location(watercourse,globe-coordinate)
- reservoir created(dam,reservoir)
- coordinate location(dam,globe-coordinate)
- country(dam,country)
- coordinate location(reservoir,globe-coordinate)
- country(reservoir,country)
- located in the administrative territorial entity(geographical feature,item)
- coordinate location(geographical feature,globe-coordinate)
- start time(dam,time)
- end time(reservoir,time)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"The Lukuga River is a tributary of the Lualaba River in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) that drains Lake Tanganyika."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Lukuga River", "origin_of_the_watercourse", "Lake Tanganyika"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "The mountains blocked Lake Kivu's former outlet to the watershed of the Nile and instead forced the lake overflow south down the Ruzizi and the watershed of the Congo."

    Ontology concepts
    geographical feature, body of water, watercourse, mountain range, mountain, reservoir, dam, drainage basin, taxon, conservation status, habitat, human, geographic region, country

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - parent taxon(taxon,taxon)
- taxon common name(taxon,monolingualtext)
- taxon name(taxon,string)
- taxon synonym(taxon,monolingualtext)
- IUCN conservation status(taxon,conservation status)
- habitat(taxon,habitat)
- parent peak(mountain,mountain)
- mountain range(mountain,mountain range)
- elevation above sea level(mountain,quantity)
- coordinate location(mountain,globe-coordinate)
- tributary(watercourse,watercourse)
- origin of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- mouth of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- length(watercourse,quantity)
- watershed area(watercourse,quantity)
- discharge(watercourse,quantity)
- drainage basin(watercourse,drainage basin)
- coordinate location(watercourse,globe-coordinate)
- reservoir created(dam,reservoir)
- coordinate location(dam,globe-coordinate)
- country(dam,country)
- coordinate location(reservoir,globe-coordinate)
- country(reservoir,country)
- located in the administrative territorial entity(geographical feature,item)
- coordinate location(geographical feature,globe-coordinate)
- start time(dam,time)
- end time(reservoir,time)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

The mountains blocked Lake Kivu's former outlet to the watershed of the Nile and instead forced the lake overflow south down the Ruzizi
the Ruzizi and the watershed of the Congo

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"From the confluence of the Little Main Restigouche River and Kedgwick River (in New Brunswick), the Restigouche river flows on 140.5 kilometres (87.3Â mi) up to the confluence, distributed according to the following segments: Higher Courses of the Restigouche River (upstream of the Kedgwick River)(segment of 31.4 kilometres (19.5Â mi)) 4.8 kilometres (3.0Â mi) to the Northeast, forming a curve to the Northwest, to the Soldiers Creek (from the east); 8.1 kilometres (5.0Â mi) North, in a curve to the East, until UpperDowns Gulch (from the southwest); 3.6 kilometres (2.2Â mi) to the Northeast, to Tracy Brook (from the West); 2.6 kilometres (1.6Â mi) to the Southeast until Haffords Brook (from the South); 1.5 kilometres (0.93Â mi) Eastward, forming a curve oriented toward the southeast until Stillwater Brook (from the east); 10.8 kilometres (6.7Â mi) North, to the confluence of the Patapedia River (from the West) which forms the boundary between the Quebec and New Brunswick."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Restigouche River", "origin_of_the_watercourse", "Little Main Restigouche River"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Rising in the Saint Cyr Range of the Pelly Mountains in southeastern Yukon, Liard River flows 1,115 kilometres (693Â mi) southeast through British Columbia, marking the northern end of the Rocky Mountains and then curving northeast back into Yukon and Northwest Territories, draining into the Mackenzie River at Fort Simpson, Northwest Territories."

    Ontology concepts
    geographical feature, body of water, watercourse, mountain range, mountain, reservoir, dam, drainage basin, taxon, conservation status, habitat, human, geographic region, country

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - parent taxon(taxon,taxon)
- taxon common name(taxon,monolingualtext)
- taxon name(taxon,string)
- taxon synonym(taxon,monolingualtext)
- IUCN conservation status(taxon,conservation status)
- habitat(taxon,habitat)
- parent peak(mountain,mountain)
- mountain range(mountain,mountain range)
- elevation above sea level(mountain,quantity)
- coordinate location(mountain,globe-coordinate)
- tributary(watercourse,watercourse)
- origin of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- mouth of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- length(watercourse,quantity)
- watershed area(watercourse,quantity)
- discharge(watercourse,quantity)
- drainage basin(watercourse,drainage basin)
- coordinate location(watercourse,globe-coordinate)
- reservoir created(dam,reservoir)
- coordinate location(dam,globe-coordinate)
- country(dam,country)
- coordinate location(reservoir,globe-coordinate)
- country(reservoir,country)
- located in the administrative territorial entity(geographical feature,item)
- coordinate location(geographical feature,globe-coordinate)
- start time(dam,time)
- end time(reservoir,time)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"The dam was built between 1941 and 1943 and created San Vicente Reservoir for the purpose of municipal water storage, flood control and recreation."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["San Vicente Dam", "reservoir_created", "San Vicente Reservoir"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Red Bluff Dam's Red Bluff Reservoir was formed in 1936 by the dam construction, organized by the Red Bluff Water Control District to provide water for irrigation and hydroelectric power."

    Ontology concepts
    geographical feature, body of water, watercourse, mountain range, mountain, reservoir, dam, drainage basin, taxon, conservation status, habitat, human, geographic region, country

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - parent taxon(taxon,taxon)
- taxon common name(taxon,monolingualtext)
- taxon name(taxon,string)
- taxon synonym(taxon,monolingualtext)
- IUCN conservation status(taxon,conservation status)
- habitat(taxon,habitat)
- parent peak(mountain,mountain)
- mountain range(mountain,mountain range)

- mouth of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)

- discharge(watercourse,quantity)

    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).

Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"The Richelieu River (French:Â [i()ljÃ¸] (listen)) rises at Lake Champlain, from which it flows to the north in the province of Quebec, Canada and empties into the St. Lawrence River."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Richelieu River", "origin_of_the_watercourse", "Lake Champlain"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Rivière des Envies (River of cravings, in a direct translation) is located in Canada, in the province of Quebec, in the Mauricie administrative region, in the Batiscanie."

    Ontology concepts
    geographical feature, body of water, watercourse, mountain range, mountain, reservoir, dam, drainage basin, taxon, conservation status, habitat, human, geographic region, country

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - parent taxon(taxon,taxon)
- taxon common name(taxon,monolingualtext)
- taxon name(taxon,string)
- taxon synonym(taxon,monolingualtext)
- IUCN conservation status(taxon,conservation status)
- habitat(taxon,habitat)
- parent peak(mountain,mountain)
- mountain range(mountain,mountain range)
- elevation above sea level(mountain,quantity)
- coordinate location(mountain,globe-coordinate)
- tributary(watercourse,watercourse)
- origin of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- mouth of the watercourse(watercourse,body of water)
- length(watercourse,quantity)
- watershed area(watercourse,quantity)
- discharge(watercourse,quantity)
- drainage basin(watercourse,drainage basin)
- coordinate location(watercourse,globe-coordinate)
- reservoir created(dam,reservoir)
- coordinate location(dam,globe-coordinate)
- country(dam,country)
- coordinate location(reservoir,globe-coordinate)
- country(reservoir,country)
- located in the administrative territorial entity(geographical feature,item)
- coordinate location(geographical feature,globe-coordinate)
- start time(dam,time)
- end time(reservoir,time)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.
